title: Can the .22 Long Rifle kill you? - Quora

response.answer_text: Can the .22 Long Rifle kill you? Oh hell yes. Statistically speaking, .22LR is responsible for the second most gun-related fatalities annually of any caliber, after 9mm Luger. The .22LR has a muzzle energy of between 120 and 180 ft lbs. That’s not much, relatively speaking; the 9mm Luger has about double that, with other common defensive handgun calibers increasing from there, and when you get into other rifle calibers you can easily find cartridges with twenty times the energy per shot. However, a hunting arrow tops out at around 80 ft lbs. If those can kill a deer, a .22 can kill a human. .22LR is not generally recommended as a defense caliber for a number of reasons, including more than a little hubris among gun owners. More practically speaking, while the .22LR is as likely to kill as many other cartridges, it’s much less likely to incapacitate. That is the name of the game in self-defense; you don’t necessarily need to kill your assailant, what you need to do is stop your assailant attacking you as quickly as you can. Larger bullets have the energy and momentum to do more “structural” damage with a greater chance to make an attacker physically unable to continue. .22LR causes most of its damage through internal blood loss, which can take up to 20 seconds to render a human unconscious. While not great at incapacitating, the .22LR remains very capable of being lethal. Among the reasons for the .22’s fatality statistics include its being the most commonly-owned caliber among gun owners (no matter what else you have, if you own more than one gun you’re very likely to own a .22 if only as a “range toy”, and despite incapacitation issues it is commonly marketed for self-defense for small size and high “density” of rounds in a given magazine volume), the number of shots required to incapacitate (while the .22, statistically speaking, required the fewest “shots to stop” on average, it also had one of the highest percentages of assailants not incapacitated by any number of hits), and the general perception that the smaller, cleaner hole of a .22 means less damage was done. When there are a lot of opportunities for a .22 to be the closest thing to hand, when you need a lot of shots to dissuade an assailant, and when your assailant is still on his feet after being shot and so can get away from not only police but prompt medical attention, the .22 tends to prove a fairly insidiously lethal round.

Yes, it can be fatal and at longer ranges than you might think. Another lawyer I know took the case of an Iraq war veteran with PTSD who bought a .22 long rifle semi auto rifle with the intention of killing himself with it. (To anyone who objects that this seems an unlikely choice for a suicide tool, especially for a former soldier trained in firearms, I have to agree, but at least that’s why he said he bought the gun). So he’s sitting in his truck at a city park thinking about ending his life when a jogger runs by on a path. Then (for reasons known only to him and God) he decides he’s not the one who needs to die that day. He doesn’t do anything right away, but waits for the runner to put 130 yards between him and his truck. Then he opens the window and shoots him four or five times in the back. The results aren’t immediately dramatic. The jogger stops, turns around and stares at him in surprise, as if to say “What the hell?!” Then he wonders off and dies. I think he ended up getting a 30 year sentence, but that’s not the point. The point is don’t underestimate the .22 long rifle. It can kill and frequently does.

An ice pick can kill you, it’s just a matter of you getting punctured in the right spot. Decades ago I worked at the County Hospital, where all the gunshot victims went, because it also had the best trauma center. Surgeons told me they would much rather treat someone shot by a .45ACP because that tended to drill right on through unless it hit a very major bone. Nice straight, clean wound channel. But if they had a .22 shooting, the bullet de-stabilized and left a ragged wound channel right off the bat, which was harder to repair. Also, it would change course inside the body, tending to ricochet off every rib, etc. that it got close to. The wound channel was not only ragged, but might go any direction(s) inside the body. A .22LR can actually be more likely to kill someone that a big-bore handgun, but a .45ACP will make someone stop what they are doing, and immediately. A .22LR will not do that unless you manage an immediately fatal shot, or one to a joint, like a knee or elbow. After the fact, though, you are more likely to die in a day or two without treatment from a .22LR than from a big-bore handgun. IT just all depends on where you are hit with what.

The .22 LR is the bullet with maybe the most penetration to bullet-weight ratios of all firearms. Such a bullet, fired from a rifle, or even a short barrelled handgun, has more than enough penetration to reach a human’s vital organs, causing death within a short period of time. The Israeli Mossad used a Beretta .22 pistol extensively as an assassin’s tool. It is very effective, and in conjunction with a silencer, deadly. You can find test videos on youtube that demonstrate the penetration of such a bullet in ballistic gel.
